questions.text: A 56-year‑old female presents in the month of December with chronic fatigue and cyanosis of nose with blue lips. A peripheral blood smear showed the following image. What is the most likely cause of the findings seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune haemolytic anemia

Option A:

The image shows agglutinated red cells. Since the his¬tory mentions that cyanosis is seen affecting fingers and tips of nose in the month of December, it suggests that the red cells agglutinated with cold antibody associated autoimmune haemolytic anemia.

Cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia (CAHA) is caused by IgM antibodies that agglutinate red blood cells at low temperatures. This typically happens in the cooler peripheral parts of the body and can lead to symptoms like cyanosis when the patient is exposed to cold environments. The condition can cause chronic fatigue due to anemia resulting from the destruction of agglutinated red blood cells.

   Explanation:

Option B. Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (WAIHA) involves IgG antibodies that react with red blood cells at body temperature, leading to their destruction by the spleen. This would not typically be associated with cold exposure and is not consistent with the symptom of cyanosis, which is related to cold.

Option C. Hemoglobinopathies, such as sickle cell disease, can cause hemolytic anemia, but the red blood cells do not clump in response to cold. Instead, hemoglobinopathies typically involve structural abnormalities of the hemoglobin molecule itself.

Option D. Cold agglutinin disease can sometimes involve IgG antibodies, but it is more commonly associated with IgM antibodies. IgG-mediated hemolysis at cold temperatures is much less common and would not explain the typical clumping seen in CAHA.

Educational Objective:

It is important to recognize the clinical and laboratory findings consistent with cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia (CAHA), where IgM antibodies bind to red blood cells at low temperatures, causing them to agglutinate. This can lead to hemolytic anemia, resulting in symptoms such as chronic fatigue and cyanosis upon cold exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 643-4

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and pallor. Her blood tests show mild anemia. Additional laboratory tests are ordered to determine the cause of her anemia. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with a diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transferrin saturation is decreased

Option C:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also known as anemia of inflammation, is a type of anemia that occurs in the setting of chronic inflammatory conditions, infections, or malignancies. It is characterized by disturbances in iron metabolism. The correct laboratory findings for the diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease are:

Transferrin saturation is decreased in anemia of chronic disease due to limited availability of iron for erythropoiesis, even though iron stores are often adequate.

  • Increased hepcidin levels
  • Transferrin saturation is decreased:
  •  Serum ferritin is increased
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is decreased

Explanation:

Option A.  In iron deficiency anemia, serum ferritin, which reflects body iron stores, is decreased.

Option B. Hepcidin levels are typically increased in anemia of chronic disease because it is an inflammatory marker that blocks the release of iron from body stores, contributing to the anemia.

Option D. In anemia of chronic disease, TIBC is usually normal or decreased, not increased, because the body's iron is sequestered due to inflammation and is not readily available for erythropoiesis.

Educational Objective:

In anemia of chronic disease, transferrin saturation is decreased due to limited iron utilization, despite adequate or increased iron stores reflected by normal or increased serum ferritin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p658

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and exertional dyspnea. Laboratory tests show a mild anemia with a hemoglobin of 10 g/dL. Further workup reveals the following: serum ferritin is elevated, total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is decreased, serum iron is reduced, and transferrin saturation percentage is decreased. Which laboratory finding is most characteristic of the anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. S. ferritin ↑

Option D:

Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by increased serum ferritin levels, decreased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), reduced serum iron, and a decreased percentage saturation of transferrin.

Serum ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and can be increased in anemia of chronic disease, reflecting the body's iron stores which are sequestered due to inflammatory cytokines.

Explanation:

Option A. TIBC is typically increased due to the body's attempt to increase iron binding capacity in response to low iron stores, which is not the case in anemia of chronic disease.

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease typically presents with decreased serum iron due to sequestration of iron within macrophages and hepatocytes.

Option C. In anemia of chronic disease, bone marrow iron stores are usually normal or increased, not decreased.

Educational Objective:

The most characteristic laboratory finding in anemia of chronic disease is increased serum ferritin, reflecting sequestered iron stores that are not available for effective erythropoiesis despite the body having adequate or increased total iron.

 

Robbins 10th/ 659

questions.text: All of the following if present provide protection against malaria except:
questions.solution:

Conditions providing protection against malaria with the reasons

 

Absence of duffy blood group: duffy antigen is required for parasite to enter the RBCs

Option B. Sickle cell disease: P falciparum cannot multiply properly in the presence of HbS α and β thalassemia:

 

Option D. G6 PD deficiency: G6PD is required for respiration of plasmodium

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group, the trait for sickle cell disease, thalassemia traits, and G6PD deficiency are all known to confer some protection against malaria due to various mechanisms that interfere with the parasite's ability to infect or survive within red blood cells. questions.text: A 30-year-old male requires a blood transfusion after a severe car accident. He is known to have the Bombay phenotype. Prior to the transfusion, his blood sample is sent to the laboratory for compatibility testing. Based on his blood group, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lack of antigens of several blood group systems

Option C:

  • People with Bombay phenotype (rarest blood group in the world) express no A, B or H antigens on the red blood cells. These are homozygous for the silent h allele (being represented h). So, these antigens are not present in the saliva also. As the antigens are not expressed, so, the H, A and B antibody will always be present in serum.
  • ABO antigens are present not only on the red blood cells abut also on the other blood cells, in most body fluids (except CSF), cell membrane of tissues such as intestine, urothelium and vascular endothelium.

He lacks antigens from multiple blood group systems: This statement is incorrect. Individuals with the Bombay phenotype only lack antigens in the ABO blood group system specifically related to A, B, and H antigens. They do not lack antigens from other blood group systems.

Explanation:

Option A. His red blood cells lack H, A, and B antigens: This statement is correct. Individuals with the Bombay blood group do not express A, B, or H antigens on their red blood cells due to a homozygous mutation in the H gene (hh genotype).

Option B. His saliva does not contain H, A, and B substances: This statement is correct. The lack of H antigen also affects the presence of these antigens in body fluids, including saliva, because the H antigen is a precursor for A and B antigen synthesis.

Option D. His serum contains antibodies against H, A, and B antigens: This statement is correct. Because individuals with the Bombay phenotype do not express A, B, or H antigens on their red blood cells, they will form antibodies against these antigens if exposed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Individuals with the Bombay phenotype lack A, B, and H antigens on their red blood cells and in their saliva, and their serum contains antibodies against these antigens.

 

Ref: Wintrobe’s hematology 12th/635-6

questions.text: The best method for estimation of hemoglobin concentration in blood is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cyanmethemoglobin method

 

Option C:

 

The cyanmethemoglobin method is considered the gold standard for hemoglobin measurement. Hemoglobin is converted to cyanmethemoglobin, which has a stable color, using a solution containing potassium cyanide and potassium ferricyanide. This method provides accurate and reliable measurements and is less susceptible to interference from turbidity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The acid hematin method involves converting hemoglobin to acid hematin using an acidic solution. This method is less frequently used due to its lower specificity and sensitivity compared to other methods.

 

Option B. Similar to the acid hematin method, the alkali hematin method involves the conversion of hemoglobin to alkali hematin using an alkaline solution. It is also not commonly used in clinical practice because it can be less accurate and is affected by turbidity caused by the presence of other substances in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to estimate hemoglobin:

questions.text: Although more than 400 blood groups have been identified, the ABO blood system re-mains the most important in clinical medicine because:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ABO (H) antibodies are invariably present in plasma when persons RBC lacks the corresponding antigen

Option D:

In clinical transfusion practice the ABO blood groups are the most important and can never be ignored in red cell transfusion, because individuals, who genetically lack any antigen, have antibodies against the red cell types that they have not inher­ited. These antibodies can destroy red cells rapidly in circulation.

The same is not the case with other blood groups where antibodies are formed only after exposure to the sensitive antigen (Preformed antibodies are absent).

Educational Objective:

The presence of naturally occurring antibodies in individuals against ABO antigens they do not possess on their red blood cells is the critical factor that can lead to hemolytic reactions if incompatible blood is transfused.

questions.text: Carbohydrate present in blood group substance is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fucose

Option A:

Fucose is a monosaccharide that is added to the precursor substance on red blood cells to form the H antigen. Individuals with the O blood group have the H antigen on their red blood cells without further modification

The first blood group antigen system was ABO and is the most important in transfusion medicine. The major blood groups of this system are A, B, AB, and O. H sub­stance is the immediate precursor on which the A and B antigens are added. This H substance is formed by the addition of fucose to the glycolipid or glycoprotein back­bone. The subsequent addition of N-acetyl galactosamine creates the A antigen, while the addition of galactose produces the B antigen.

Explanation:

Option B. Deoxyribose: Deoxyribose is a sugar found in DNA, not associated with the ABO blood group antigens.

Option C. Ribulose: Ribulose is a pentose sugar involved in metabolic pathways, like the pentose phosphate pathway, but it is not related to blood group antigen formation.

Option D. Ribose: Ribose is a sugar component of RNA and is not involved in the structure of ABO blood group antigens.

Educational Objective:

Fucose is added to the glycolipid or glycoprotein backbone of red blood cells to form the H antigen.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the chromosomal locations of blood group antigens. When considering the Rh blood group system, including the Rh antigen, which of the following chromosomes houses the relevant genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1

Option A:

The Rh blood group system involves two genes, RHD and RHCE, which are located on chromosome 1. The specific chromosomal location for the Rh antigen is on chromosome 1.

Educational objective:

The gene for Rh antigen is present on chromosome 1.

questions.text: All are seen in Thalasemia major except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Macrocytic anaemia

Option D:

Macrocytic anemia is typically associated with disorders of DNA synthesis, such as vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, not thalassemia major, which usually presents with microcytic (small cell) anemia due to defective hemoglobin synthesis.

Explanation:

Option A. Transfusion dependency is a characteristic of thalassemia major, as patients often require regular blood transfusions to manage severe anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis.

Option B. Splenohepatomegaly in thalassemia major results from extramedullary hematopoiesis, where the spleen and liver try to compensate for the anemia by producing blood cells, and from iron overload due to repeated transfusions.

Option C. Ineffective erythropoiesis refers to the bone marrow's inability to produce mature and functional red blood cells, a hallmark of thalassemia major due to mutations affecting hemoglobin production.

Educational Objective:

Thalassemia major typically presents with transfusion dependency, splenohepatomegaly, and ineffective erythropoiesis but not with macrocytic anemia, which is more consistent with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 638

questions.text: Bone infarcts are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

Option C:

Sickled cells can cause microvascular occlusion affecting bones, brain, kidney, liver, retina and pulmonary vessels.

Sickle cell anemia is well known for vaso-occlusive crises, which can lead to bone infarcts due to the occlusion of small blood vessels by sickled cells.

Explanation:

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia usually presents with symptoms related to a lack of hemoglobin and oxygen delivery, such as fatigue and pallor, not bone infarcts.

Option B. Thalassemia can cause bone deformities due to marrow expansion but does not typically cause bone infarcts.

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis typically involves hemolysis and anemia due to defects in the red blood cell membrane, but it does not usually result in bone infarcts.

Educational Objective:

Bone infarcts are a common complication in sickle cell anemia due to vaso-occlusive events caused by the abnormal, sickled red blood cells.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 640)

questions.text: A 18-year-old Afro American boy presenting with a non healing ulcer of the foot, with recurrent pneumonia and chronic hemolytic anemia. The peripheral blood erythrocytes showed some peculiar appearance. Most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Single amino acid base substitution

Option C:

Afro American male presenting with the mentioned features is suggestive of sickle cell anemia is due to vaso-occlusion caused by sickled cells. Sickle cell anemia can cause chronic hemolytic anemia, recurrent pneumonia and non haling painful ulcer.

“Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin that leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue” … (Ref: Robbins)

 Single amino acid base substitution, specifically a point mutation in the β-globin gene (glutamic acid to valine at the sixth position), is the cause of sickle cell anemia. This mutation leads to hemoglobin polymerization under hypoxic conditions and the characteristic sickling of red blood cells.

Explanation:

Option A. Trinucleotide repeat expansions cause disorders such as Huntington's disease and some forms of muscular dystrophy, not sickle cell anemia.

Option B. Genomic imprinting is a form of gene expression regulation that does not relate to the structural changes in hemoglobin seen in sickle cell anemia.

Option D. Antibody to red cell membrane would suggest an autoimmune hemolytic anemia rather than a genetically determined structural hemoglobinopathy.

Educational Objective:

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single amino acid substitution (valine for glutamic acid) at the sixth position of the β-globin chain of hemoglobin, which results in the sickling of red cells and related complications.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 648
